Survey: What's Your Favorite Movie Set on a Train?

Banksy's Dismaland Isn't Actually the Unhappiest Place on Earth
items.dek: Banksy's ironic, artistic, and rebellious take on the theme park succeeds on many levels.
items.body:
[#image: /photos/55e70632cdd1761348bddad9]||||||





Just how dismal is [Dismaland](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2015-08-20/banksy-theme-park-dismaland-is-opening-in-england)? Early signs are encouraging. The line outside the heavily-fortified, long-derelict lido on a particularly windswept stretch of Weston-super-Mare, England, is vast, barely moving, and menaced both by pranksters in seagull costumes and the park's own gimlet-eyed, mouse-eared operatives, who mutter bon mots like “go home, it's crap.” What are they waiting for? Admission to a little patch of surrealism in the English beach "resort" town in Somerset that's been transformed by graffiti guru Banksy into an anti-theme park of “art, amusements, and entry-level anarchism.”

Once through security checkpoints (one real, one cardboard, both spewing invective), you find yourself in a compound that resembles an Occupy camp hours after a messy clearance; powdered concrete crunches underfoot, a half-submerged police truck's roof-mounted water cannon serves as an impromptu fountain, and Hawaiian hula music drones through loudspeakers and bounces off the walls. 


[#gallery: /galleries/53daa9b26dec627b149f9eaf]||||||





Banksy's own centerpiece—a jerry-rigged castle housing a tableau of a fairytale princess in a crashed coach whose death throes are being captured by paparazzi—is merely the most bombastic of the artistic one-liners on display. There are the paintings of felled and bleeding trees; installations of menacing mushroom clouds made of cotton; to Brit house-music pioneer [Jimmy Cauty](https://twitter.com/jamescauty?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Eauthor)'s elaborate model village under siege by riot police, and Jenny Holzer's Situationist-style slogans like “Ambition is just as dangerous as complacency" periodically interrupt the slide-guitar strains in lieu of missing-child announcements. 


[#image: /photos/55e706324cb36d1b2f0e324b]||||||





The longest lines bypass the Sisyphean amusements such as Turner nominee David Shrigley's sideshow-esque game Topple the Anvil—in which anyone who manages to dislodge an anvil with a set of ping pong balls wins the anvil—in favor of the agitprop, including a bus housing a display of “architectural cleansing” (such as the notorious "anti-homeless spikes" that have sprung up in cities across the world), and a direct-action tent where you learn how to break into bus-stop signage cases and substitute the corporate ads for messages of your own (such as “Unf-ck the System”).

Despite the presence of hucksters from as far afield as Portugal, Japan, and California, Dismaland taps into a very British strain of blunt-instrument satire, heady belligerence, and resolutely lowered expectations. It's a scabrous joke at everyone's expense, including Banksy's; for all the jokes directed at capitalism, its success can't help but reinforce the commodified nature of his brand. As you—naturally—exit through the gift shop (Dismaland-logo T-shirts, destined for a hefty resale on eBay, abound), you feel that it's less the “bemusement park” your wristband promises than a one-stop playpen where prejudices are confirmed—for or against art/fops/theme parks/the very idea of compulsory fun in a dispirited British seaside resort—and, thus, it can't lose. Outside the door, two men—clad in skinny jeans, big boots—are comparing their purchases under the lowering sky.

“Grim, wasn't it?” says one.

“Really was,” says the other.

They couldn't look more delighted.  



----------


[#image: /photos/55e70636cdd1761348bddaf7]||||||





        


----------


[#cnevideo: /cnevideos/55a548347772ff921f95ea7c]|||
Third Place: Life and Travel by Your Own Design
|||

fields.name: Stuart Husband
fields.shortBio: London-based journalist Stuart Husband has, quite literally, trekked to the ends of the earth in pursuit of stories, sailing round Cape Horn, going on safari in Botswana, tramping the salt flats of the American west on a pilgrimage to the monumental land Art sculptures of the '60s and '70s, and embarking on a culinary tour of Ethiopia, for titles such as *Monocle, Four Seasons, Robb Report,* and *Sainsbury's* magazines. Nearer home, he's profiled everyone from Dame Vivienne Westwood to Woody Allen for the *Telegraph, Observer, Sunday Times,* and *Independent*.
fields.title: Freelance Writer

items.hed: The Best Things to Do in Beijing's 798 Arts District
items.dek: Set in the formerly industrial Dashanzi area, this neighborhood in China's capital bustles with edgy art and culture.
items.body:
[#image: /photos/55d4b7d9c47ae13868ae8ea2]|||
UCCA focuses on contemporary Chinese artists.
|||





Built as a Bauhaus-inspired factory complex in the 1950s, Beijing’s 


[#activity: /activities/53eae57cdd4d6a0b75efc71e]||||||





 has gone through a massive transformation—from a bustling industrial park to a hub of working artists’ studios to a mecca of modern Chinese art and design. Slightly northeast of central Beijing, 798 is packed with galleries, design shops, cafes, and hipster tourists. The district plays host to performances and installations throughout the year, and the daily crowds of art students and China’s next generation of young, audacious artists are as fascinating as the works in the galleries.

__Here are six spots you should seek out in 798:__



##[Ullens Center for Contemporary Art](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/beijing/ullens-center-for-contemporary-art-ucca) (UCCA)

Since its inception in 2007, 


[#activity: /activities/55d3c048c47ae13868ae7dbe]||||||





 has been the cornerstone of the district. UCCA puts on 15 exhibitions a year across its four galleries, focusing on contemporary Chinese artists. Exhibitions are supplemented with a strong program of lectures, film screenings, and workshops that unite international and Chinese experts. Plus, don’t miss the excellent UCCASTORE Art Space, full of cutting-edge everyday objects and special pieces that, like the UCCA motto says, “Bring Art into Your Life.”

##[Magician Space](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/beijing/magician-space)

This is an intimate gallery that specializes in Chinese avant-garde and encourages audiences to interact with the exhibitions. 


[#activity: /activities/55d3c0d7c47ae13868ae7e15]||||||





 aims to address “the blind spots” in Chinese contemporary art by curating exhibitions that excite and confuse. It recently mounted Ai Weiwei’s solo exhibition, *AB Blood Type,*a major site-specific installation of cast-iron pieces of grass covering the gallery’s two exhibition rooms. Shows feature a rotating roster of rising Chinese artists, internationally acclaimed provocateurs, and collaborations between the two.

##[Spin Ceramics](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/beijing/spin-ceramics)


[#shop: /shops/559d47a97772ff921f95b102]||||||





 is a wild departure from the Beijing markets full of with replica vases and cheap pottery. The elegant and beautiful ceramics are full of personality and humor, combining modern sensibilities with ancient Chinese technique and craftsmanship. The handmade pieces—like folded pots, vases with cheeky faces, and delicate saké bottles—make for perfect gifts or one-of-a-kind souvenirs. Spin has expanded to Shanghai and New York but the Beijing store is still our favorite.

##[Fei Space](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/beijing/fei-space)

A boutique by artist Lin Jing and fashion designer Ray Lee, 


[#shop: /shops/55d3c27f37284fb1079cdc81]||||||





 is the perfect place to browse emerging Chinese designers and quirky household pieces such as antique rugs and tea sets. The thoughtfully selected wares—Alexander Wang sunglasses, clothing by local designer Zhang Da, eclectic retro furniture and lighting—are artfully displayed in Lin’s former home.  Plus, Fei Space hosts installations and pop-up collaborations, creating a truly immersive shopping experience.

##[Cafe Flatwhite](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/beijing/cafe-flatwhite)

A Kiwi café serving fresh juices, avocado-laden salads, and full English breakfast with yogurt and fresh fruit, 


[#restaurant: /restaurants/55d3c35cc47ae13868ae7e88]||||||





 boasts some of the best coffee in the city.  Beans are roasted locally by Rickshaw Roasters and coffee is made in the Antipodean style—think creamy flat whites and strong long blacks. The café has two locations in 798, including an outdoor patio space by the D-71 Park, which is perfect for afternoon lounging, people-watching, and posting your snaps to Instagram via the free Wi-Fi.

##[Beijing Yi-House Art Hotel](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/beijing/beijing-yi-house-art-hotel-798)

Housed in a former crystal factory, 


[#hotel: /hotels/55d3c44137284fb1079cdd13]||||||





 is a modern, stylish boutique hotel with an incredibly friendly staff that can keep you up to date with the latest openings and shows in the district. Inside, there's the perfect mix of Chinese and international design sensibilities—lacquered benches and ceramics in the classical Chinese style juxtaposed with large-scale graffiti murals. In case the neighboring galleries weren’t enough, the rooms feature works from contemporary Chinese artists. The hotel restaurant is also a great place to start or finish your gallery tour with either a decadent brunch (Western-Chinese fusion) or cocktails in the open-air garden. 


----------


[#cnevideo: /cnevideos/55a548360121edec25703168]||||||

items.hed: Survey: What's Your Favorite Movie Set on a Train?
items.dek: Train travelers apparently have a sinister side, given the results of a recent Vacations By Rail poll. Respondents to the survey, conducted this spring by the industry specialists, love a good murder on the rails...

items.title: #1. Murder on the Orient Express
items.caption: The most popular train movie with 30 percent of the vote, *Murder on the Orient Express* thrilled much like the Agatha Christie novel that inspired it—thanks to Detective Hercule Poirot.

items.title: #2: Doctor Zhivago
items.caption: Russia's haunting beauty is front and center in this 1965 romantic epic, which came in second with 25 percent. Many of the film's most pivotal scenes occur on the rails, including Zhivago's bitterly cold ride on a cattle train through Russia's mountains.

items.title: #3: ￼￼￼￼￼￼Strangers on a Train
items.caption: Trains become a murder planning point in this 1951 Alfred Hitchcock crime thriller, which came in third with 13 percent.

items.title: #4: Polar Express
items.caption: On its heels was the classic children's book-turned-movie *Polar Express,* with 12 percent of the vote. The 2004 film is guaranteed to turn even Santa non-believers into a pile of Christmas mush.

items.title: #5: North by Northwest
items.caption: Cary Grant's Roger O. Thornhill first meets the mysterious Eve Kendall on a train in this 1959 Alfred Hitchcock thriller, which got 11 percent of the vote. Thornhill tells Kendall that trains are his preferred method of transportation because "there's no place to hide on a plane if anyone should recognize me."

items.title: #6: Silver Streak
items.caption:
Gene Wilder's 1976 comedy-thriller *Silver Streak* takes us for a murderous ride on a L.A.-bound train from Chicago; this rounded out the list with 7 percent of the vote. 

Are your favorite films missing? Let us know on [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/CondeNastTraveler) or on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/CNTraveler).
For more travel in pop culture, check out our lists of the [50 Best Travel Movies of the Past 50 Years](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2015-01-07/50-best-travel-films-of-the-past-50-years), and the [20 Greatest Road Trip Movies](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2015-08-07/the-20-greatest-road-trip-movies).

fields.name: Rachel Coleman
fields.shortBio: Rachel Coleman is the Social Media Coordinator at *Condé Nast Traveler.*
fields.bio: Rachel Coleman joined *Condé Nast Traveler* as the Social Media Coordinator in March 2014. Before joining the team, she served on the social media and editorial teams at Disney and NBC's iVillage. A journalism graduate of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, she enjoys traveling (duh), eating tons and tons of Mexican food, and dreaming about the day she can finally own a puppy.

items.hed: The Mob Museum Welcomes FIFA to its Halls
items.dek: The Las Vegas museum debuts a new exhibit, The 'Beautiful Games' Turns Ugly, on September 1.
items.body:
[#image: /photos/55bbaee86966466e2ce304b2]||||||





Just how corrupt is FIFA, the governing body of the world's most popular sport? Enough that it's getting its own permanent spot at a museum dedicated to the world of organized crime, jostling for exhibition space with John Gotti's leisure suit and a .38 from the St. Valentine's Day Massacre. In September, Las Vegas's Mob Museum will open __[The 'Beautiful Game' Turns Ugly,](http://themobmuseum.org/press_releases/the-beautiful-game-turns-ugly-new-mob-museum-display-explores-corruption-of-fifa/)__ an exhibit that will wade into the sludge pit of corruption that has plagued the Fédération Internationale de Football Association for decades.

Why the not-so-honorable distinction? In a way, FIFA operates much like a global, billion-dollar crime family: no government oversite, no taxes paid, and decades of widespread venality that led to a multinational investigation earlier this year. A pair of inquiries spearheaded by justice departments in the U.S. and Switzerland led to a scene straight out of a mob movie—a raid on FIFA's Zurich headquarters in which 14 of the organization's officials were arrested. Bribes for broadcasting rights in the neighborhood of $150 million? Votes bought to ensure World Cup hosting rights? Money laundering? Fraud? Fixing games? FIFA has been accused of it all. 

The Mob Museum's exhibition will examine FIFA's numerous sins piece by piece, using photos, newspaper clippings, and other ephemera to delve into the complicated story. Ex-FIFA president Sepp Blatter (who resigned his post in June) may be in a permanent time-out, but soccer fans will have plenty to chew on until the next World Cup rolls around.

*The 'Beautiful Game' Turns Ugly opens September 1 at the Mob Museum in Las Vegas, NV.*


[#activity: /activities/53eae5bbdd4d6a0b75efc89a]|||
The Mob Museum
|||

fields.name: Jenna Scherer
fields.shortBio: Jenna is a Brooklyn-based writer, editor, and rouser of rabble.
fields.bio: Jenna is a writer, editor, and pop-culture critic whose work has appeared in *Rolling Stone, Hemispheres Magazine,* Made Man, *The Boston Herald,* Time Out Boston, and The Watershed Post. Most recently, she was associate editor at *Time Out New York.* Journalistic research has taken her from the catwalks of haunted theaters in Boston to helicopters over Manhattan. When traveling, she can usually be found climbing to the tops of very tall things. She lives in Brooklyn.

items.hed: Spin Cities: Must-See Record Stores Around the World
items.dek: Records are having a moment. From Argentina to Japan to Iceland, these are the shops you should seek out—and the sounds you should pick up—in your quest for some of the world’s greatest vinyl.
items.body:
[#image: /photos/55ca514f84775cba0a7baa2f]|||
Rough Trade in London.
|||


##Rough Trade, London, United Kingdom

What began as a small punk-rock label in 1978 has, over the years, transformed into one of the world's best LP-focused mini-chains, with additional outposts in Nottingham and Brooklyn. Both London’s Rough Trade East and West are notable for hosting free in-store performances and exhibits, as well as carrying releases from up-and-comers in the music world. But Rough Trade East wins in terms of size—the 5,000-square-foot former brewery has a larger performance stage—and better selection.

__Take home:__ The Smiths’ debut studio album, *The Smiths,* which was originally released in 1984 on Rough Trade’s independent label.


##Big Love, Tokyo, Japan

Nestled in the Harajuku neighborhood, Big Love is an independent record label and shop known for carrying obscure artists in lesser-known genres—think Japanese "harsh noise" music and cult artists like Chicago's Gel Set. Browse records (and new cassettes—yes, they're back) while sipping craft brews like Nagano’s Shiga Kogen; the tiny shop also has a bar with a rotating draft list. 

__Take home:__ *Bliss,* the debut album from Danish metal band Reverie, released on Big Love’s own label. 

##The Funkiest, Helsinki, Finland

Finland might be considered strait-laced, but The Funkiest helps show that appearances aren't always what they seem. Open since 1995 next to the popular Hietaniemi Park, this influential store has the country’s best selection of Finnish hip-hop. Though it specializes in the latter—selling the genre on CD, vinyl, and even cassette—it also has a globe-spanning selection of jazz, soul, and funk LPs from the ’60s and ’70s on vinyl.  

__Take home:__ Anything by Huge L, one of the most popular Finnish underground rappers.

##Tongues, Vienna, Austria

Indulge all five of your senses at this record shop, organic deli, and cafe, which is a short walk from both the Museum of Fine Arts and the Museum of Natural History in the city’s MuseumsQuartier. Flip through rare reggae LPs while waiting for your homemade vegetarian lunch combo to be ready, or stock up on house-cured meats and cheeses from the counter and take your picnic to go. 

__Take home:__ Staff recommendations on the newest Austrian electronica. 

[#image: /photos/55ca514ed36458796e4cb76f]|||
Porchlight in Seattle.
|||

##Porchlight, Seattle, Washington

While Seattle institutions like Easy Street and Sonic Boom have more inventory and name recognition, quality—and coffee—trump quantity at this hybrid record shop and café, where you can pair a cup of Herkimer joe with organic Mighty-O Donuts. Rifle through new and used vinyl selections from a wide variety of bands while looking out for releases from Porchlight’s own, carefully curated label, which showcases some of the best burgeoning rock talents—Grand Hallway and Keaton Henson, for starters.

__Take home:__ *Fog On The Lens*, from Seattle native Tomo Nakayama.

##Minton’s, Buenos Aires, Argentina

Record stores in Buenos Aires are a dime a dozen, but few are as steeped in history than Minton’s. Its name, an homage to the New York jazz outpost of the 1930s, nods to its selection, which is like catnip for jazz aficionados. Here, you’ll find the classic (Monk, Coltrane, Davis), the contemporary (Paula Shocron Trio, Craig Taborn), and ever-present discussion between owner Guillermo Hernández and musicians, artists, and writers on all things jazz. 

__Take home:__ Adrián Iaies Trio’s *Las Tardecitas de Minton's,*which was named for the store, and a bottle of Minton’s own Malbec, if you can find it. 


[#image: /photos/55ca515584775cba0a7baa4d]|||
ZudRangMa in Bangkok.
|||

##ZudRangMa Records, Bangkok, Thailand

A verifiable treasure trove of rare Thai vinyl, ZudRangMa hosts a number of other regional obscurities like mŏr lam and luk thung—Laotian songs of unrequited love and Thai songs about rural hardships, respectively—that make it one of a kind. If that weren’t enough, the store also has its own record label, radio shows, and house DJs.

__Take home:__ '60s Thai funk from Phiangpit Sirivilia.

##12 Tónar, Reykjavik, Iceland

A nondescript house on Skólavörðustígur Street, this three-floor shop, record label, and hangout spot has been a hub for the Icelandic music scene since it opened in 1998. Head to the back room, where you can relax on couches—much like members of Sigur Rós used to do before they were famous—and listen to potential purchases before you buy. Staff will even bring you free espresso and tea. 

__Take home:__ Award-winning Icelandic musician Ólafur Arnalds’ reinterpretation of classical music, *The Chopin Project,* with German-Japanese pianist Alice Sara Ott, from 12 Tónar’s own label.


[#cnevideo: /cnevideos/55a548310121edec25703110]||||||

fields.name: Katherine LaGrave
fields.shortBio: Katherine LaGrave grew up on the island of Okinawa and currently lives on the island of Manhattan.
fields.bio: Katherine LaGrave is a journalist and photographer whose work can be found in *Outside, Popular Science, BBC Travel, Vanity Fair, National Geographic Traveler*, and *The New York Times*. She has lived in Germany, Indonesia, Japan, Greece and the United Kingdom.
